qas.question: Who was the first Indo-Greek king who did not rule from Bactria?
Who succeeded or ruled alongside Apollodotus I?
What religion did Menander I convert to?
What was Menander I refered to by in Buddhist texts?

context: After Demetrius' death, civil wars between Bactrian kings in India allowed <a0_0>Apollodotus I<a0_0/> (from c. 180/175 BCE) to make himself independent as the first proper Indo-Greek king (who did not rule from Bactria). Large numbers of his coins have been found in India, and he seems to have reigned in Gandhara as well as western Punjab. Apollodotus I was succeeded by or ruled alongside <a1_0>Antimachus II<a1_0/>, likely the son of the Bactrian king Antimachus I. In about 155 (or 165) BC he seems to have been succeeded by the most successful of the Indo-Greek kings, <a2_0>Menander I<a2_0/>. Menander converted to <a3_0>Buddhism<a3_0/>, and seems to have been a great patron of the religion; he is remembered in some Buddhist texts as '<a4_0>Milinda<a4_0/>'. He also expanded the kingdom further east into Punjab, though these conquests were rather ephemeral.
